description: Ask up to 10 questions to guess the profession on the Game Card! Do people in this profession wear a uniform? Do people in this profession perform on stage? Is the profession a singer? Think hard, ask intelligent questions, use your clue cards wisely, and the be the first player to win 7 Game Cards!

Yakatapé is similar to the Whac-a-Mole arcade game. It is fully mechanical and does not need batteries.

During play, players launch the timer and the five plastic ghosts pop up randomly. Players try to crush as many ghosts as quickly as they can with the plastic hammer.

Each time a ghost is crushed, the counter underneath automatically increases by one point. When time is up, players add up the point counters. The player with the highest number of points wins.

"Yakatapé" in French means "All one has to do is punch!"

On the summer solstice, the longest day of the year, on the wild, faraway island of JUNGLA, two fearless packs – the KNIGHTS commanded by the powerful LION CAYDEN and the PIRATES led by the cunning TIGER DHURTA – battle for the TAWA HALLAE, the scepter of power of the animal world.

THERE CAN ONLY be ONE KING! A terrible struggle is underway to reach the enemy hunting squares. Animals fight duels to the bitter end, in which each animal has unique fighting abilities. 
Luck won’t decide the outcome of this contest. Let the battle cry ring out: Brave in the melee, loyal to the KING! Only the side with the most courage, strategy, cunning, and speed will emerge victorious.

SUMMARY OF RULES 
There are 2 packs, each consisting of 15 animals. Each animal moves in different directions and a specific number of squares depending on its abilities. The direction and number of squares 
permitted for each move depends on whether the animal starts from a land or a water square. Hit animals are imprisoned and removed from the board. The aim is to take the animals in your pack from the den squares to the enemy hunting squares, achieving a point. The first pack to score 5 points or to imprison all the enemy animals wins.

—description from designer

Plata is a climbing card game where players enter an abandoned mine in the ghost town of Silver City in search for Plata (silver).
The goal is to win Plata cards, the only ones that score points. The lower the card, the more points it provides.
Players also must be aware of the Mine’s Curse that prevents the last player to leave the mine (to go out of the round) to score any of the points earned during the round.

—description from the publisher

For Words is played with a deck of cards, most showing a single letter. There are also some wild cards and blank cards.

The game starts with each player having five cards and two on the table. On their turn a player must add a single card to the table to form a new word. Cards can be played before, after, in between, or on top of the current cards. Blank cards can be played on top of letters to effectively erase them.

If a player can't play they draw until they can.

The object is to either play all your cards or force the other players to have at least ten. The game is normally played in multiple rounds with scoring.

Potions & Puppies is a light weight game that has a unique twist on resource management and press your luck. It's a 1 to 5 player cooperative game where all players must work together to share resources to discover recipes to a variety of potions to help you get past tasks inside the tower. Each puppy has a unique magic ability to help their friends but must balance using their own abilities with using those same crystals for potions.

Puppies have a variety of actions to take on their turn ranging from gathering crystals from a shared stash to discovering or brewing potion recipes. Each puppy also has two unique abilities - a lesser ability can be used an unlimited number of times per game as well as a once per game ultimate ability that will make the puppy's player mat flip and their remaining ability will cost more gems to use for the rest of the game. Discovering potions is vital to puppies' success, and each time a player wants to discover a potion they must use three colors of crystal from in front of them that do not match any other current recipe before flipping over the top potion card. Potions can be be brewed by using the same crystals as are on the recipe card by placing them onto the puppies' current tile. When all potions have been brewed, the puppies can move forward.

Brewing a potion that is labelled on the modular tile they are currently standing on allows the group to move forward and one step closer to escape. They also have unique abilities such as rearranging recipes, looking at the potion deck to see what is coming up next, and digging up many crystals at once. At the end of each turn the active player can draw up to two crystals from the blind bag to replenish their resources - but each time a black crystal is drawn the guardian moves one space closer to the puppies and the crystal goes back into the bag. If the puppies brew all the potions on the final tile before the guardian lands on their current space - they win! Otherwise, it's game over.

-description from designer

Power Play is an abstract hockey-themed game. Each person controls three hockey players, numbered 1-3.

On a turn the owner's players must each be moved to an empty adjacent space if possible, and they must be moved in numerical order. After that, the puck is checked to see how many of the current players are adjacent to it, and it is moved that many spaces in any combination of directions.

Moving the puck into the opposing goal scores a point. The first player to score three points wins.

Part of the Ridley's collection - mix and match with the different puzzles, games, and nostalgic toys in this brand!

Containing 200 quiz cards, there are 1000 questions to test even the most knowledgeable 1990s expert!

Fun bar quiz style game split into 10 different categories of 100 questions from the 1990s - sports, movies, music, and much more!

Each player has a personal stack of cards with farm animals of different sizes. They draw four of these into their hands (three when playing with three players). One by one, they place a card into the middle, forming a 3x3 grid (4x4 with 4 players). When the grid is complete, players receive one point for each row (orthogonal or diagonal) in which they placed the highest card. Whoever has most points after five rounds, wins the game.

OXx is a game system with cards. The rules contain four ways of playing, the publisher has announced that further rule sets would be published on their website.
The cards have three properties: A background color, a word (blue, yellow, etc.) and a color in which this word is written. Most rule sets are based on finding cards with two matching characteristics, you will then try to get rid of them by stacking them up, either player by player or in a speed mode.

This is a game about Cologne in the Middle Ages designed to pass on the forgotten or buried knowledge. It was originally intended for graduates of the Akademie för uns Kölsche Sproch, who took their diploma there in the form of a knowledge quiz.

Players roll dice to visit Cologne's historical sights, but they can only move further after they have answered a question correctly. There are a total of 451 questions. The winner is the player who have visited all the sights and put down the corresponding card.

It's harvest season! Put your tractors to work, be savvy and cash in your valuable crops at the end of harvest to finish on top!  In this card drafting game, you must judge the market and predict what your fellow farmers will do as you try to collect the best hand of valuable crops!

Harvest Crunch takes the card drafting of Sushi Go! and gives it a twist, as different types of crops are worth different amounts each round. Select valuable crops and cash them in but, only if you can sell them before your opponents take up all the room in the elevators! To guarantee you can sell your crops, collect tractors. If you have the most tractors you get to sell your crops first!

Collecting combines doubles the amount you receive for crops. Collecting silos allow you to save crops until they are at their most valuable. Have the most money by the end of the game to win!

—description from the designer

Win duels by playing cards of matching or higher value to defend your hand or sacrifice your lowest card. When you're on your final card, lowest card wins the round bringing Tacocat closer to their side.

Tacocat Spelled Backwards is a fun balance of strategy, luck and instinct! With its portable open-and-play design, it's a perfect two player anytime, anywhere game; the box is the board, just open and play!

What's Included
7 colorful palindrome tiles.
38 delightful and hilariously illustrated palindrome cards with values from 1 to 12 for strategic card match ups.
1 adorable token of Tacocat, the ICONIC character from the Exploding Kittens game.

Call your friends and venture into the Enchanted Forest in search of treasures, but beware, it is full of dangers.


     On your turn, discard a character card from your hand and


move your pawn to the next square where there is an icon of that character.

     When a player plays a character card that takes him to a space containing a score marker, it collects the score marker from the top of the pile.
     The game ends when the last castle token is collected, even if other score markers along the trail have not yet been collected.

A drop of Acid is a stacking game about trying to get the most highest balls of your type. But watch out! At any point one of the players can drop a bomb to destroy all it touches.

—description from the designer

Goblin Horde board game puts you in charge of a ramshackle horde of Goblins!

The goal as chieftain will be to collect as many treasures as possible. To do this, you will use your subordinates of questionable intelligence.

Choose your team of Goblins, each with their own characteristics and abilities, catch the adventure and get ready for various dexterity challenges!

Who will be the most precise or creative will take home the coveted treasure! But be careful! The Goblins are very quarrelsome and the fight is always around the corner.

—description from the publisher

A Lenda do Herói is based on a videogame known internationally as "Songs for a Hero", developed by Dumativa and Castro Brothers. It can be played cooperatively or in "hero team vs. villain" mode.
Players take turns singing verses which must contain a rhyme determined by the villain. They should try to include as many of the items depicted on open cards on the table, because they can take any of these item cards as coins. At the end of a round, the group can buy extra skills and lives for the coins they collected. 
The villain's role is to make the hero team's task more difficult, because when a player fails to create and sing a musical verse within time and conditions, the hero loses a life, and if the team loses all their lives, the villain wins. There are 3 levels of difficulty of the rhyme cards, so the Villain needs to manage the difficulty of the rhymes in their hand and analyze which ones are more difficult with the elements that are currently on the table. If after three rounds the hero team still has lives, there is one last round. In this final round each player must use all the elements on the table, and the sung stanza needs to be a provocation to the Villain. If a player succeeds, the villain is hit. If the Villain receives a number of blows equal to their life, the hero team wins.

Players take turns placing tiles to connect roads. Straight edge must connect with straight edge and curved edge must connect with curved edge. If a player cannot connect a tile's straight edge to another that is already in play, he/she may use a bridge to connect to a curved edge. The player with the least tiles when no further moves can be made is the winner.

Try to avoid Scar and the hyenas as you travel through the African savanna.
Collect tokens as you make your way around the game board—4 matching tokens gets you the win!
Exciting and engaging gameplay provides a whole new type of Lion King experience.

—description from the publisher

It's 1927. The streets of Sydney, Australia, are rife with thugs, hustlers, dealers, forgers, bookies, pimps, working girls and hard men. Sharks.

Do you have what it takes to secure your place as a crime lord of Sydney? Manage your cash, fuel your determination, build up your street gang and plan for the day when you finally take on one of the kingpins. And don't let your determination wane, lest the street sharks devour you.

Sharks is a deck-builder in only 9 cards, but featuring 36 real-life criminals from 1920s Sydney. Your hand of 4 comprises your gang, and you must use their resources to avoid, recruit or crush the adversaries you meet in the street. As you recruit better members to your gang, your adversaries also grow in strength. To win the game you must confront and crush one of the four acknowledged crime lords of the era: drug lord Charles Passmore, club king Phil Jeffs, sly grog queen Kate Leigh, or the formidable madam Tilly Devine.

—description from the designer

Travel around the city of Kobe and take the best photos to win the game!

In Zoom in Kobe, players compete in a photo contest to try to take the best photos of the city. During the game, you take photos of its beautiful locations, the iconic structures found in Kobe, and...weathercocks, one of the symbols of Kobe!

The goal of this board game for 2-6 players is to score the highest number of points to win the photography contest. When a player takes their eighth landmark photo, the game ends, then the photographer with the most points wins. Points can be scored by:


    Taking photographs of the landmarks selected by the judges, with bonus points awarded if the photos contain the relevant themes of the game (different themes will be revealed for each game)
    Taking photographs of the different buildings of the skyline of the city.


This game contains 75 landmark cards with beautiful illustrations of locations of the city of Kobe. First time players learning the basic mechanisms of the game, or those who want a shorter play time can play with the Photography Starter Kit version.

Swappies is a game based on permutation and domination which can be played by 2, 3 or 4 players. This strategy game is played on a checkered big board with 81 squares arranged in a 9x9 grid. There are 2 ways to win;  being the only player remaining on the board or to place all 49 swappies on the big board.

Try to form patterns to create clones of your swappies. By doing so, you may replace opponent's swappies. You can also encircle opponent's swappies to get more clones and get rid of more enemies.

Basically, the idea behind Swappies was to create a game where good players in Candy Crush Saga (or any similar games) could play against each other. Also, there is no kind of luck, this game is just all about skills.

—description from the designer

Swappies est un jeu de permutation et de domination pouvant être joué par 2, 3 ou 4 joueurs. Ce jeu de stratégie est joué sur une grande planche de jeu contenant 81 cases dans une grille de 9X9. Il y a 2 façons de gagner; être le dernier joueur à avoir perdu tous ses swappies ou mettre ses 49 swappies sur la grande planche de jeu.

Essayez de faire des combinaisons afin de créer des clones avec vos swappies. En faisant cela, vos clones prendront la place de certains swappies ennemis. Vous pouvez encercler les swappies de vos adversaires pour avoir plus de clones tout en se débarrassant de plus de swappies ennemis.

En fait, l'idée derrière Swappies était de créer un jeu auquel les joueurs de Candy Cush Saga (ou tout autres jeux similaires) puissent s'affronter l'un l'autre. Aussi, il n'y a pas de coup chanceux, ce jeu n'est basé que sur les aptitudes.

—description from the designer (French)

Gotcha! is played on a 5x5 grid. Each player has a set of pieces numbered 1-25.

On each turn one player places a piece face-down in a column or row and the other then places a piece face-down in a row or column so that the intersection of the two is an empty square. The numbers are revealed and both pieces are placed in the square with the higher on top, indicating that it won. (A tied square is unowned.)

When all pieces have been played players score a point for every square and bonus points for orthogonal lines of at least three squares.

D-Day to Berlin is a fast playing game designed to recreate corps level battles of the Second World War, using miniatures to represent the combat battalions and counters to represent the supporting air and artillery assets.

As a general commanding one or more Divisions, you must decide how to make the best use of your battalions, detachments, and supports to fulfill your assigned objectives.  
The game is designed to give a sense and feel of the war at this level of operation and still be a fast and fun game.

In this game units are battalions and in some cases company-level detachments. The game is large scale with a turn representing 2-4 hours. A day is 6-8 turns with a night time turn.

It can be played with 15mm troops with an infantry battalion stand being 50mm x 30mm (Flames of War basing).
The table is divided up into 6″ square blocks called zones.  Each is about 2.3 to 3 miles square.
Players are at a minimum a Division commander with 8-12 battalions and artillery support.
Experienced players can control 2-3 divisions which makes them a corps commander.

–description from the designer's website

Bomb Run is designed to provide the framework of an immersive and sometimes emotional experience that may or may not have a happy ending. No mission will be the same but it is your story and your imagination forms the narrative.

Each game simulates a World War II Bombing mission over Europe in a B17G Flying Fortress. Each mission builds on the last mission with the ultimate objective to get as much of the 10-man crew through the required 25 missions.

Players will physically mark on the crew cards to show their record of downed enemy planes and completed missions. Use a sharpee. The cards are coated with a UV protection which allows you to clean your card off with an alcohol swab to reset it.

Bomb Run is a solitaire, deck-in-hand, card game. That means there is no table-top required and the entire game fits in the player’s hand. Each mission takes on average less than 10 minutes but it can easily be put away and picked up later and continued mid-mission.

Every player runs an animal shelter with a mission to help as many dogs as possible find forever homes. Fueled with adorable artwork, this fast-paced game is great for family and friends alike. Kids can learn strategy, patterns, addition and subtraction, while adults get the thrill from adapting to new strategies with every play.

Not only do you get to help dogs finding loving homes in this game, you'll also make some dreams come true for amazing doggos in real life!
 For 3-6 players. The game includes 162 cards, dog token, manual and box.

GAMEPLAY

Too Many Doggos takes only 5 minutes to learn. Many people will visit your adoption event, and you'll do a meet and greet with them. You’ll compete with each other to help dogs find a loving home by matching their unique traits with a person’s interests.

To increase the chance of a successful adoption, give any dog an edge with positive action cards. If you don't think there's a good match for a doggo, you can also use a negative action card to block the potential adoption. 


Get the most well matched dogs adopted from your shelter to win, and give many doggos the life they deserve with a loving family.

Sanctuary: The Keepers Era - Lands of Dawn is a competitive, fast paced, hand management card game, the starting chapter of a story which takes place in a brand new fantasy setting.

The game features three unique Faction decks illustrated with  stunning artworks by a team of international artists.

According to the legends of Elnerth, a powerful mystic energy was flowing dangerously through the world. To avoid catastrophic events, that energy was split into six parts called the Essences.

Sanctuaries are the only way to channel the power of the Essences. Players impersonate the Keepers, each one is attuned to an Essence and rules over a Faction. The Keepers are fighting each other to preserve their Sanctuaries and themselves. The goal of the game is to destroy all the oppponent's Sanctuaries, to become the only Keeper able to shape the fate of the world through their Essence.

Choose your Faction, each one with its own peculiarity, and dive into the dark and wondrous world of Elnerth.

—description from the publisher

The weirdest fighters will clash in epic battles using their own unique set of skills, mind games, and finishers! Hit your opponents hard, knock them down and be the Champion of KAPOW FIGHT!

In KAPOW FIGHT players must program their round using action cards that enable them to do a variety of techniques.

Every round of the game, players must choose 3 of their Basic Action cards to play face down in a specific order.

Depending on the game mode, in order to become the Champion of KAPOW, you need to Knockdown opponents more than once.

The name means "The game of the exact number".
The object of the game is to make mathematical equalities with cards. These ties can be independent of each other (rule A) or dependent on each other (rule B).

Rule A:
The player chooses from his 9 cards those which allow him to establish a tie. For example 4 = 4 or 4 + 2 = 6. There can only be one sign on each side of the = sign. Each tied tie will be worth points according to the value of the cards. If he cannot lay a tie, he must draw a card and get rid of a card in hand. The round ends when a player empties his hand. He then obtains a bonus of 50 points. The first player with 1000 points wins the game.

Rule B :
The game begins the same way as rule A with 8 cards instead of 9 for each player. The player must re-use one card already on the table to build their equality, using the same building spirit as the scrabble game.

This game, described as "astrological", has its theme about divination through the stars and tarot cards.
It includes a solo mode which is more a self divination than a game and a duo mode which is a game.

Each player has 12 cards in their hand. The first player thinks of a question and mentions its theme to the other player. The theme can be health, feelings, money, work ... He then turns the plate on the board in order to bring his number (determined from the transcription of the letters of his first name into numbers) in the area of â€‹â€‹his astrological sign. He then moves the "sun" disc on the board so that the green solar ray is on the sign of the other player. This indicates 3 numbers which correspond to constellation maps. If the player has a matching card in his deck, he places it in front of him. If he doesn't have one, he passes and the other player moves the discs on the board to identify 6 more digits. When all the cards have been identified, the players compose their answers using the booklet supplied with the game. The players then assemble the cards according to their symbols and sort them in numerical order. The player with the highest row of cards wins

—user summary

Set of XIX century board games reprinted:
Post- und Reisespiel (Gustav Kühn)
Ringwürfel-Spiel (Johann Trautner)
Tiergarten Spiel (F C Wentzel) BGG Item ID: 177491
Neues Matrosen-Spiel (Gustav Kühn) BGG Item ID: 58035
Turnierspiel (Robrahn & co)
Gänsespiel (Pellerin & Cie.)

A party game for adults only.

Cards are divided into two groups, the Red (or Black depending on which version you have)cards consist of fill in the blanks or question cards. The white cards are possible answers to teh red cards.

Each player holds 10 white cards. One person selects a fill in the blanks or question card from the appropriate pile.  The remainder of the players choose one of their 10 cards in hand which they feel best matches the reader's card. The first person reads all the answers and selects their favorite. The person whose card was chosen gains the point. Play proceeds around the table until everyone has a chance to be the reader. The amount of points required to win can be a predetermined number.

Bazaar Exchange is a market-based board game where players trade objects, create products, and attempt to win total market dominance.

Players each start with an inventory of object cards with specific products able to be made for the game. Each product is comprised of specific objects, so players decide which products they want to try to create, then trade with other players to get the products that they need.

After trading is complete, the final round, the Bazaar Exchange, commences.

Every round, players secretly place a bid. The tribe with the highest bid wins 1 ingot and loses their bid to the 
second highest bidder. The tribe with the second highest bid loses their own bid (goes into the game bank) but takes the highest bid instead. All other tribes get to keep their bids.
The tribe(s) with the lowest bid (50 dribs or more) get 50 dribs from the bank.

A winner is declared when a tribe is able to collect 3 ingots.

—description from publisher

Bad, Bad, Turtle comes as part of a single deck of cards that offers up a number of different game options.  The two primary game options the deck allow for are Bad, Bad, Turtle and a game called Fubnub.

Bad, Bad, Turtle is a quick paced, easy, game that requires you to have more luck than your opponents. Equally inspired by the card games 'War', 'Uno', and 'Exploding Kittens', Bad, Bad, Turtle includes a mix of features from each of those games plus a number of its own little wrinkles to make for just the right amount of silly fun in every quick game.

Designed for 2 to 4 players ages 5+. The average play time is about 10 minutes. The winner is the player who avoids all the geckos and is the first to find the turtle.

—description from the designer

They came from space. From within meteors they broke out and caused devastation. With corporations and security companies concerned only with the elites, the people pleads for world government action. The president of the world is then forced to finance mercenary giant robot pilots, paying for each head of the giant monsters.

Project HUNTER is a minimalist solo print-n-play roll-n-write game in which you drive a giant robot in order to defeat the giant monsters that have invaded the earth. You will need to print these sheets and get some dice, pencils and eraser.

Objective
The main objective of this game is to defeat at least one monster of each of the six species. However, you must survive until then! Your giant robot is destroyed if its chassis is completely damaged or if it overheats, which will cause an explosion. You also lose if you run out of money after a hunt.

Hunting Kaijus
To face a monster you first roll three dice. Each die will indicate a monster avaliable. Of these three you will have to choose one to face. If you don't want to face any, you will have to spend $ 50 on the maintenance of your robot to be able to wait another day. So you can roll the three dice again. You start the game with $ 300 in cash (write it down).

Combat
As soon as you choose a monster to face the combat starts. The combat is separeted between the turn of the monster and the turn of the robot. The monster always starts first.

Monster Turn
On the Monster turn you must roll a number of dice equal to the Monster Attack value. Each die is treated individually and allocated somewhere in the robot sheet. Each die that landed at number 6 causes 1 Overheat. Each result less than 6 can be absorbed in some armor of the robot. See in the diagram of the robot that there are squares for you to write down the result of the die you want to allocate there. You can place it wherever you want as long as there are already any other results linked to it, it must obey the rule (see below). If you cannot allocate any die in the sheet this die becomes 1 damage in the Chassis.

Armor’s Rules
In the diagram of the robot you will find several blank boxes to record the result of a die. Each of these boxes has an arrow. If the arrow is facing the box, it means that it has some rule. Each symbol on the black circle will indicate he rule.

Robot Turn
On the Robot's turn you will be able to choose if you want to attack normal with your weapons or if you want to overload the shots. If you choose to attack normal, roll the dice equal to the number of weapons you have (initially you only have one weapon). Add up all the results of all the dice and write down the amount of damage the monster has taken. If the monster loses all hit points, it is defeated (see below).
If you choose to do an overloaded attack, you will roll twice the attack dice but will cause 1 point of Overheating.

—description from the publisher

The crow glares from its gargoyle perch as crumbs of granite fall from the decaying structure. You hear the creak of the nearby door too late to dodge the hand that pulls you inside and presses you against the wall. The smell of the rotting timbers floods your nostrils. Your assailant removes her mask - It is the Muscle. 
‘‘Once again you’ve been careless with your steps.’’ You say nothing. 
‘‘The Baron refuses to leave Schloss Böse, so we must go to him.’’ She hands you a wax sealed envelope, then disappears into the darkness. You tuck the envelope, step back into the street, and disappear into the fog.

Nine Ravens is a deck and tableau building game for 2 to 4 players. Each players represents rival guilds of thieves, insurgents, and trouble makers known as Ravens vying for control of the city as the Baron’s grasp loosens. By stealing powerful artifacts and relics, each organisation hopes to emerge the victor when the moon disappears.

The game is played through five rounds where they will use their Raven cards to steal, claim and store items to earn points at the end of the game.  At the end of five rounds, players will tally their points, with the highest number determining the winner.

—description from the publisher

The players, as residents of Lazy Town, take turns rolling dice, moving along the board and completing various assignments.

Assignments can include doing light workout, eating healthy snacks, or complimenting an opponent.

For each completed assignment, the players receive one fruit or vegetable token.

When a player has collected enough tokens, they need to face Robbie Rotten and successfully complete one final assignment to win the game.

Meridian is a medium weight space exploration game for all ages. It's easy to pick up and  dynamic mechanics allow for many different routes to victory.

In the game you colonize different planets which each have unique abilities and may trigger a new technology to emerge or cosmic events to take place. Players must shift their strategies to deal with new and changing threats present on the board and by other players.

Battle of GOG is a board game set in the ancient land of Canaan. Battle of GOG challenges all family members to find 5 sacred scrolls as they battle over the land of Canaan.

Game rules are simple, combining strategy and luck equally, so anyone can win. The game is easy to learn, but hard to master. Despite simple mechanics, game play involves complex strategic thinking. The map of the game can be assembled in numerous combinations, so each game session plays differently. Establishing 3 cities in the most abundant map areas won`t ensure your victory, as Ability Cards and Treasure Chest Cards can make the difference in a critical situation. And remember, GOG has the power to save you from the Angel of Retribution!

Battle of Gog is played over a series of rounds until at least one of the three winning conditions have been achieved by any player:
1) Long Variant: Conquering all other player's cities. Short Variant: Conquering the last city of any of the players.
2) Placing a soldier at each of the 4 corners of the map.
3) Obtaining all 5 Scrolls.

Each turn, the active player follows 4 phases in the following order:

    Gathering and trading resources
    Buying upgrades
    Playing treasure cards
    Rolling the dice


In the first few turns of the game, there will be no cities, so no resources can be collected.

—description from the publisher

Inspired by the historical legacy of Colonel Percy Fawcett, Z, Lost Trails is a strategy deck-building card game with both competitive and cooperative game modes. The game progresses through 3 stages as you prepare your finances in London, gather a team and resources in South America, and finally embark on an expedition through the Jungle. This game is designed to challenge your ability to plan ahead, out-maneuver, and survive one of the most legendary quests the world has ever known.

Deep in the dark jungles of the Amazon rainforest, lies hidden a lost city known only as Z. It may be in the center of a nearly impenetrable forest, along an undiscovered black river, deep in some snake infested canyon, or on top of a lonely, craggy peak, guarded by denizens from a forgotten time. This archeological marvel only awaits discovery from a courageous and intrepid explorer such as yourself. Many have gone in search of it, but few have returned to regale their friends and colleagues with the tale of their sufferings and defeat. This game allows you the opportunity to be a turn-of-the-century explorer; taking you from your living room to the dark and dangerous recesses of South America. Combat poisonous snakes, deadly spiders, tropical diseases, murderous savages, and untimely mishaps on your quest to find the lost trails to Z, a city of great riches, personal bliss, and just possibly the answer to your most profound questions and desires. Select your character and fulfill their dream. But remember, you need to embark properly outfitted with porters, mules, weapons, supplies, and medicines, if you are to have any chance of finding the clues that can insure your survival and, just possibly, success.

—description from the designer

Which good thing is gooder—Brunch Mimosas or Seeing a Bunch of Hot Air Balloons? Air Conditioning or A Clean Public Restroom? 272 Debate Cards and 36,856 possible pairings make up Good vs Gooder, a party game where teams create random matchups and debate which good thing is gooder. Let's share stories, laugh together, and start spreading some goodness!

All players divide into three teams and draw five Debate Cards. Two teams submit their favorite Debate Card. The third team flips over the two Debate Cards and judges Round 1. Teams try to persuade the judges with stories, jokes, real-life experiences, and fun facts. After a few minutes, the judges deliberate and vote for which team was more persuasive.

The winning team draws either a Good Card or a Gooder Card. All Good Cards are worth one point. Some Gooder Cards earn teams more than one point. Some are worth negative points. And some are action cards (like forcing your opponent to impersonate a celebrity during the debate). Teams must decide whether to play it safe or take a chance!

After Round 1, rotate which team judges and keep playing until you've completed 12 total debates. Whichever team has accumulated the most points after the last debate is declared the Goodest of All Time!

—description from the publisher

Fertile Ground is found all over the world, and as a Gardener, you endeavor to find and Sow the unique flora of the globe in your own Garden. As your Garden grows, your plants help and guide you along this path, accelerating your progress while also necessitating thoughtful orientation of new plants in your Garden. But you're not alone; other Gardeners are watching, and working just as hard to create the most productive Garden by the end of Winter - and only one will prevail!

Gardeners begin with a hand of between 1-7 of the 200 unique Plant Cards and work to Sow these into their Garden. As they do so, they will need to Collect resources (Soil, Sun, Water, Seed) to pay for the cards as well as make sure that they have appropriate space where each plant can survive. Taking turns, Gardeners collect resources, gather cards, and Sow plants into their Gardens; as they accumulate more plants and their associated abilities, their capacity to do each of these increases drastically. The game proceeds through the four seasons (rounds) in which each Gardener has a set number of turns, and at the end of each season Gardeners Pollinate their plants to gather Harvest. At the end of Winter, the value of the accumulated plants, resources, various tokens, and more determine the total value of each Garden, and thus the winner of the game.

—description from the designer

Become one of the friendly, hard-working Scandinavian tomten, completing tasks in preparation for St. Knut's day. Players will compete to collect task cards for a mix of instant rewards and engine building by working and resting their way through the holiday season.

A game takes place on a calendar-themed board beginning on December 1st, culminating on St. Knut's Day on January 13th. Tasks performed will cause resources to be spent, but resting (and some task rewards) can bring those resources back into the ready position. As players collect task cards, they'll build an engine by adding each card's rewards to their train of completion rewards when working, playing, or partying on holidays.

At the end of the game, players will all join together for St. Knut's Day and score final victory bonuses based on the artwork shown on cards they've collected throughout the game. Each card features a unique illustration by Jenny Nyström, a Swedish painter and illustrator famous for her works featuring the jultomte performing tasks throughout the Christmas season.

—description from the publisher

At the dawn of man, tribes fought against both nature and others of their own kind to secure their slim chance at survival. Their ability to adapt and evolve in the face of constant hardship allowed the strongest of those tribes to succeed. You are in control of one of these tribes, and their future is entirely in your hands.

PrimEVO is a miniatures agnostic skirmish system intended to be played solo or among a group of people. It offers quick gameplay (1 vs 1) and offers not only world challenges that all tribes must face together, but also those that they will have to overcome individually. Literally no two campaigns will be alike.

—description from the designer

You are not alone...

Escape from Mars is a single player hidden traitor game.

An alien virus has infected the crew of Mars Base Epsilon, the first off world colony, and strange insect like creatures swarm the outpost. Players must discover and quarantine the alien host, living among them, inside one of the crew, they must also gather alien gene samples, then via the communication room, request rescue. It’s a race against time as crew become infected, drone aliens will be drawn to the colony until eventually an alpha alien will arrive and wreak havoc on the colony and its crew.

Scour the colony for useful items and weapon, locate the clues to discover the alien host and send them to quarantine, keep crew infection down, research the alien gene sample codes, deal with crisis events and distrustful crew members, seal off parts of the base and set defenses, send the robot to rescue fallen crew, prepare medicines and vaccines, stock up on ammo, jump in a space suit and search the plant surface, destroy the alien drones then hold out until the rescue ship arrives, just make sure you get home...alone.

The game is played over a set number of rounds (which also determined the difficulty), a crew marker counts down the rounds and at the other end of the round tracker an Alien marker moves in the opposite direction, if the markers ever meet, the Alpha Alien will arrive and the ‘Host’ crew member will die.... or evolve?

Players start off with a limited number of active crew, some must be rescued, other will be distrustful and need convincing to join. Player must scour the ship looking for clues as to the identity of the Alien Host, looking for blood samples and crew logs, players also need to gather alien samples for HQ. The colony is also full of weapons, tools, events, and more. Players risk crew when venturing out in colony as the longer they search, the more exposure to the alien virus they risk. The game is about managing and taking risks, use your crew wisely as they have different strengths and weaknesses.

The game ends and the players win, when they have discovered and quarantined the Alien Host, found and reported the Alien samples to HQ, all get into the airlock and the rescue ship arrives.

The player loose if no one makes it out alive, and this can happen in many ways...

Celebrate the hit ’90s TV show in this hilarious head-to-head party game that will challenge what you know about the “show about nothing.”

Score points by answering trivia questions, charades-style acting, and guessing who said or did some of the most hilarious bits ever aired on television! You’ll even get a chance to fish for the marble rye like George and Jerry did!

It’s hundreds of Seinfeld-celebrating activities for outrageous fun!

Players will form teams of two and each turn roll the challenge die. There are five types of challenges and one "Newman!" icon. The different challenges will be asked to the current team and if they get them correct they will score some points.

The first team to 70 points or more wins! However if both teams have at least 50 points, one team may skip their regular turn to attempt the Marble Rye dexterity challenge (yes, just like the show!)

-description from publisher

The Sound of Metal is a fully cooperative (or solo) tabletop miniatures skirmish game. With a rogue-lite campaign system, players take on the roles of survivors of humans, trying to get by after the downfall of civilization, a result of the Great Robot Uprising.

After a large meteor crashes into the planet, the Robot overlords start to experience communication issues and many start to malfunction. Humans dubbed this event as "The Glitch" and see it as their opportunity to take back their planet. This is no easy task, as the human population is just a fraction of what it once was, and communication is a challenge. Although the Robots have been greatly disrupted, they are still, in every sense of the word, a great threat.

Players create survivors, find a vehicle, and traverse the countryside, gathering resources, finding food and weapons, and learning skills to complete mission objectives. In doing so, players characters will level up, gain notoriety, and try to find and destroy the machines central core.

The game features an action-point based system - These points double as action points and your characters health. As your character takes wounds, they lose action points. Run out of action points, and you collapse.

Combat/skill checks are performed by rolling dice, bolstered by stats and gained skills.

Similar to the great tactical, turn-based video games of the 90s, such as X-Com and Jagged Alliance, players can spend extra action points to perform actions at higher levels of competency, being able to aim, change their stances, or focus on specific tasks.

Enemies are controlled by the game's AI  - each enemy has its own order of operations reactionary programming. Players face these enemies in campaign missions, as well as random encounters.

The world unfolds in front of the players - as they track their progress on the overworld map. Moving costs food and fuel, and dangers lurk around every corner. The map is be randomly generated each game, and players will find settlements, points of interest and missions in different areas every game.

Players never control more than 6 survivors at a time, and can be played with 1-6 players cooperatively, splitting up the survivors among players.

—description from the designer

The life of the little stuffed Teddy comes to life at night, his duty is to take care of the dreams of his child, throughout the hours of the night he must go through a series of adventures with the aim that his child wakes up as calm possible, but you must be careful, the world of nightmares is open and Little Guss is prowling the room, you will have to collect as many magic buttons as possible to help protect your child's dreams.

The Teddy's Adventures is a roll & write style game but with buttons instead of dice, it is played by taking colored buttons out of a bag, from these buttons the active player will choose which buttons will be painted in each section of his game sheet and which button It will be eliminated, in addition to which button the other players will paint, the game sheet will fill with colors as the rules explain, and you will have to check the progress of the board of the world of nightmares that can trigger the end sooner than provided. Once the end of the game is triggered, points will be counted in each section of the sheet and the player who scores more points than the others will win.

—description from the designer

Horizon Wars: Infinite Dark is a science-fiction spaceship tabletop miniatures wargame. It allows for solitaire, co-operative, and competitive versus play. Players create a fleet of ships, customizing both their statistics and their heroic pilots. When played solo or cooperatively,  the AI adversary is controlled through an AI and a standard deck of playing cards. Scenarios are objective-based and range from one-off encounters to narrative campaigns, complete with character progression.

MONOPOLY GAME: THE LORD OF THE RINGS EDITION: Protect the lands of Middle-earth from the armies of Mordor with this Monopoly game inspired by The Lord of the Rings movie trilogy
RING OF POWER: Control the Ring and get special powers, but beware! The longer a player has the Ring, the more dangerous it becomes. Rolling the Eye of Sauron can make someone pay a heavy price
MEMBERS OF THE FELLOWSHIP CHARACTER TOKENS: Play as Frodo, Gandalf, Sam, Aragorn, Legolas, Gimli, Pippin, Merry, or Boromir
PATH TO MOUNT DOOM: The player who has the Ring also moves a Ring Tracker along a line of circles on the gameboard toward Mount Doom. Lose or give away the Ring and the Tracker moves back to Start

—description from the publisher
